citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the contingency plan, program of veterinary care, and environmental enhancement program for
non-human primates and birds, were not available for review by the inspector. Review of records required by the Animal
Welfare Act facilitates the inspection process by allowing the inspector to determine compliance and evaluate animal
welfare. The facility shall ensure that the records required to be kept by the Animal Welfare Act and the regulations are
available for USDA APHIS officials to examine. Correction date: September 21, 2023.

The facility, which houses primates and other exotic animals in outdoor enclosures, does not have an adequate perimeter
fence. Most of the premises is surrounded by a perimeter fence that is less than 6 feet tall and covered in overgrown
vegetation. A perimeter fence protects animals from contact with unauthorized people and animals. A perimeter fence
also acts as a secondary containment system if an animal escapes from its primary enclosure. Correct by installing a
perimeter fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out, and to act as a secondary
containment system for animals in the facility. Alternatively, a variance may be requested in writing from the APHIS
Administrator. Correction date: October 30, 2023.

Three primary enclosures for birds are in need of repair.
*Ten adult macaws are group-housed in an outdoor wire enclosure that contains multiple sharp points and excessive rust.
The sharp points and rust are frequently found throughout the wire panels around the enclosure.
* 39 chickens and 1 ring necked pheasant are housed in a wire outdoor enclosure which contains multiple sharp points
and excessive rust. The sharp points are found around the automatic water receptacles as well as loose wire panels
throughout the enclosure.
*53 chickens and 4 guineafowls are housed in a wire outdoor enclosure which contains multiple sharp points. The sharp
points are found around areas that the birds frequent such as the water and food receptacles.
Enclosures with sharp points may cause injury to the birds within. The facility must ensure that all primary enclosures be
constructed and maintained so that they have no sharp edges that could injure the birds. The primary enclosures must
also be kept in good repair. Correction date: September 28, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.126(a)(2) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
At the time of inspection, the contingency plan, program of veterinary care, and environmental enhancement program for 
non-human primates and birds, were not available for review by the inspector. Review of records required by the Animal 
Welfare Act facilitates the inspection process by allowing the inspector to determine compliance and evaluate animal 
welfare. The facility shall ensure that the records required to be kept by the Animal Welfare Act and the regulations are 
available for USDA APHIS officials to examine. Correction date: September 21, 2023. 
3.78(d) 
   
Outdoor housing facilities. 
The facility, which houses primates and other exotic animals in outdoor enclosures, does not have an adequate perimeter 
fence. Most of the premises is surrounded by a perimeter fence that is less than 6 feet tall and covered in overgrown 
vegetation. A perimeter fence protects animals from contact with unauthorized people and animals. A perimeter fence 
also acts as a secondary containment system if an animal escapes from its primary enclosure. Correct by installing a 
perimeter fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out, and to act as a secondary 
containment system for animals in the facility. Alternatively, a variance may be requested in writing from the APHIS 
Administrator. Correction date: October 30, 2023. 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Three primary enclosures for birds are in need of repair. 
 
*Ten adult macaws are group-housed in an outdoor wire enclosure that contains multiple sharp points and excessive rust. 
The sharp points and rust are frequently found throughout the wire panels around the enclosure.  
 
* 39 chickens and 1 ring necked pheasant are housed in a wire outdoor enclosure which contains multiple sharp points 
and excessive rust. The sharp points are found around the automatic water receptacles as well as loose wire panels 
throughout the enclosure.

*53 chickens and 4 guineafowls are housed in a wire outdoor enclosure which contains multiple sharp points. The sharp 
points are found around areas that the birds frequent such as the water and food receptacles. 
 
Enclosures with sharp points may cause injury to the birds within. The facility must ensure that all primary enclosures be 
constructed and maintained so that they have no sharp edges that could injure the birds. The primary enclosures must 
also be kept in good repair. Correction date: September 28, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
